{
"step_by_step_thinking": "The given case report describes a patient with mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (MLNS) without exanthema. The symptoms of MLNS typically include fever lasting more than seven days, conjunctival injection, changes in the mouth consisting of erythema of the oropharynx, 'strawberry tongue', and erythema of the lips; indurative edema of hands and feet with palm and sole erythema followed by desquamation of the fingertips. The patient also has lymphadenopathy, pyuria, aseptic meningitis, diarrhea, arthritis, and arthralgia.

The current case presents with painless subcutaneous nodules on the back of the wrist, outside elbow, and front of the knees, as well as inflammation in the joints of the lower extremities. This is consistent with the symptom complex of MLNS.

Renal failure is not mentioned as a typical feature of MLNS.

Hepatomegaly is also not mentioned as a typical feature of MLNS.

Chorea is an involuntary movement disorder that is not typically associated with MLNS.

Pleural effusion is not mentioned as a typical feature of MLNS.

Based on the symptoms presented, the most likely symptom to be present in this patient is arthritis.",
"answer_choice": "C"
}
